I went with three of my friends and decided to order family style.  We got the tea leaf salad, coconut chicken soup, spicy fish, chicken curry, and chin baung jaw shrimp & sour leaf.

If this isn't highlighted enough in the other reviews, the tea leaf salad was AMAZING!  I was extremely impressed how fresh the leaves were and how flavorful the marinate was.  We only ordered one dish for the four of us and it wasn't enough.  I'd recommend 1 for every 2 people unless you plan on filling up with a variety of dishes.

Coconut chicken soup is probably one of my favorite burmese dishes because it's almost at every family party I've been to so my relatives get a lot of practice making it.  While it was still pretty good at Burmese kitchen, I wasn't mind blown.  But again, it's hard for me to judge. I think it's worth trying if you haven't had it before.

We had the spicy fish and chicken curry with coconut rice and I'd HIGHLY RECOMMEND you do the same!  This is definitely a dish I'd get the next time I come here.  The chicken was very tender and would fall off the bone and paired perfectly with the rice.  The fish was a little too hot for someone in our group, but if you're fine with spicy food it was this is also a must!

If you're looking for something uniquely Burmese, I'd give the chin baung jaw shrimp & sour leaf a try.  Admittedly it was a little weird for two of my friends since sour food isn't really popular in most cultures but if you want to be adventurous I think this is definitely something different.

tldr; The must haves are the tea leaf salad and coconut rice with chicken (and spicy fish if you can handle heat).  
If you want to try something more unique to Burmese culture try the coconut chicken soup but stay safe and if you're adventurous the chin baung jaw.
author: Edric K.

description: I ordered the chicken tikka masala off eat24 from here - i'm pretty sure it was bat meat next to cow bones.  It was less than 20% bat meat.  So bad - worst take out i've ever had in San Francisco, maybe they reserve the chicken meat for people that eat in....
author: Austin t.

description:
We have ordered takeout about 10 times now. We always order the same things --- Rainbow salad, tea leaf salad, coconut noodle soup. 

I was going to get it four stars but I bumped it up to five stars because of two things. Consistency and speed. These items are consistently the same and consistently really good. They also make their food relatively quickly which is much appreciated for takeout. Combine that with reasonable prices and you get five stars from me!
author: Sai S.

description:
Hadn't been to Burmese Kitchen since it was on Larkin. I don't know how long they've been at this location, but I'm really happy to report that the food is still as good as it was back in its Larkin days. I remember being so bummed when they shut down that location and went back a few times hoping they'd reopen soon. After a few times looking them up, I forgot about it and it wasn't until my sister's birthday, which just passed, that we thought of looking for Burmese Kitchen. 
Same faces, same yummy food, but open later, which is a plus!
author: Lorry T.

description:
The menu shows two different tea leaf salads. The only difference I could see was something about extra tea leaves and one had tomatoes while the other didn't. I ended up asking, and it turns out both have tomatoes, one just has more tea leaves.

While I enjoyed the house tea leaf salad a lot, the two other things we ordered weren't just disappointing, they were gross and thinking of them now, a few days later, makes me feel disgusted. The combo fried platter was overly fried and quite crispy, with an unimpressive sauce. The coconut noodle soup was the worst--it had a weird texture that stuck to my mouth, the coconut milk might have been a bit sour or something, the flavor wasn't great, and the crunchy things (no idea what they were) tasted burnt.

tl;dr: Get the house tea leaf salad and nothing else.
author: Michelle G.

description: We came in about 20 minutes before close yet were greeted kindly, without the typical annoyed looks restaurant staff reserve for guests keeping them late. We ordered the house special tea leaf salad, garlic noodles with shrimp, and chicken biryani. Both the noodles and the biryani were outstanding, and the leaf salad also did not disappoint. In sum: delicious food, great service, and affordable prices. Plus they serve food until 10. A+.
author: Yana Y.

description: We dropped by for a quick meal after Ft Funston and were really pleased. We got the signature tea leaf salad, fish chowder and lemongrass beef. All three dishes were flavorful and not very pricey, especially compared to the other local sf Burmese restaurants.
author: Julie H.

description:
Probably my favorite restaurant in the city. They've been great since their prior location in the Tenderloin, but I feel like they've gotten even better at their new Geary spot. Their dishes are generally more varied and delicious than at other nearby Burmese establishments.

First off, this is the only place I know of that has tamarind leaf salad. I love tea leaf salad, but their tamarind leaf salad is a notch above. The soups and the stews are fantastic; the sauerkraut pork is the one I always go back to. But I try something new every time and they never disappoint.

The prices are extremely reasonable too, for what you are eating. I would call it $$$ food at a $ price.
author: Les P.

description: Got the Egg Noodles/Garlic dish with chicken and the coconut rice. My friends got the lemongrass beef and coconut chicken. This was my first Burmese food experience and it was honestly nothin to write home about. The main reason why I'm writing this review is because there were tiny gnats/flies literally hovering all over our food. I noticed them about five bites in and completely lost my appetite. I'll update this post if I get food poisoning...
author: Nicole C.

description:
I called ahead to make sure MSG wasn't used. The guy said they didn't use it at all. When we got there the waitress informed my mother, who gets terrible migraines from MSG, there were only two or three vegetarian dishes without it. She ordered one of them. Still, she got very sick the next day and for the next three. 

Other than that the food was mediocre. Not terribly tasty but well priced. Won't be back.
author: Mark F.

description: Had their tea leaf salad which was one of the best I've had in SF!  I feel like it had more toasted nuts, beans and seeds than other places and had more flavor as well.  The roti paratha was a bit underdone, but was not too oily which was nice and the curry sauce it came with was rich in flavor.    We also tried the fish stew noodles which was comforting, with a good combination of textures from the crispy samosa like crackers and toasted mung beans.  Noodles could have been less soggy though and would have liked to see more fish.  All in all a solid meal and will def be back.
author: Olivia T.

description: I'd say Burmese Kitchen is closer to 4 and a half stars, but I'll round up for this review (pending future visits, of course). Chose Burmese Kitchen for a random Thursday lunch, due to the very reasonable entree prices (the lunch menu is a good deal). The tea leaf salad is currently the best I've had. The rainbow salad, while full of flavors, lacked the synergy of flavors that I've come to expect (three and a half stars, I'd say). The restaurant is small and the service is friendly and attentive. I'd like to visit again to try the catfish chowder soup and nan gyi thohk.
author: Tyrone V.

description: Best Burmese in the City - way better than any of the popular known options. We have been coming here regularly for more than 1.5 years. We still discover new dishes and are amazed by the variety of flavors and dishes.
author: Hans G.

description:
Strongly recommended for lunch.  They have a set of lunch specials for $10 to $12 which should pretty much cover everyone's tastes.  

And really, BK is currently the best Burmese food in the city.  Definitely better than Superstar.  Get some of their more interesting salads, like the ginger salad or the rainbow salad.
author: Josh B.

description: There's nothing very Burmese about this place besides the name. The decor is very sterile. The food isn't spicy or taste like it contains any trace of south East Asian spice. There was an option for coconut, fried or plain rice. If there were two ways to make plain rice worse, try the other two options. Had this curry braised beef, it was tough. Had some curry noodles that tasted like something from a chinese restaurant. And some other unmemorable dish.
author: Elton F.

description: Yes we had the same experience of waiting an hour or enjoy a Burmese meal without the wait. Fabulous tea leaf salad and super spicy chicken curry so beware.
author: Monica R.

description: Great local takeout spot! Ordered the tea leaf salad, veg soup and lemongrass beef. Delicious!
author: LA R.

description:
get the regular tea leaf salad. very peanuty tho.
roti was oily and over priced. just 1 piece for $6+
coconut curry was creamy. awesome when mixed with coconut rice.
overall everything was good, but not very memorable.

if anything, try the salad, as thats the only thing that really stood out.
author: Jason C.

description: I'm the big fan of Burmese foods and I have to tell you guys that this restaurant is way much better than Burma Superstar on Clement St.   Focusing on the foods, Burmese Kitchen offers you a great chicken and beef biryani, many great curry which its meat is not cooked too well-done or too harsh (compare to B Star). Also, they offer an amazing Mo-Hing-Ya (Burmese style fish chowder) ... Way way much better than B Star as well. ....,, people plz don't wait an hour for B Star. Come here!!
author: Rachel T.

description:
I'm a huge fan of Burma Superstar and Mandalay! When this place opened up in my hood I figured based on the reviews it would be amazing. 

We started off with the tea leaf salad which to me had way too many nuts and lentils. Very crunchy and the presentation wasn't like how Burma presents it. I was not a fan.
We then ordered the combo platter appetizer. Let me just say none of this was homemade, rather frozen and deep fried upon ordering. The samosas and falafel were exactly like the ones you get from trader joes frozen section. Totally let down.

For our main entrees we had the pork with pickled mango, garlic noodles and coconut rice. The pork was the only dish that had flavor and was actually decent. The meat was tender and has a well balanced array of spices. The garlic noodles however came in a huge blob and stuck together, very bland. Sadly the coconut rice cannot compete with burmas. There was not even a hint of coconut.

Sorry Burmese kitchen but I won't be returning.
author: Kehaulani K.

description: Don't go anywhere else for Burmese food - the food and service here are superb! Several things that you must try...Tea Leaf Salad, Combo Fried Platter,  Fish & Sour Leaf Soup, Spicy Fish & Chicken Biryani. There are so many other things on the menu that are delicious but these dishes are above and beyond so good! The soup and spicy fish are definitely spicy but if you can handle the spice - try them!
author: JoAnn C.

description:
Came here excited to try this place out thinking it would be good given that it's in a close vicinity with a few good Burmese restaurants in the area, but apparently that is not the case. 

The food here is very bland and disappointing ! The potato curry was very watery and bland w/ little curry taste. The fish chowder was bland and comes w/ a lot of nuts. The chicken curry was bland and you'll have to order rice separately cause it doesn't come with any. Lastly, the Burmese fried rice is just plain rice with nothing in it, no meat or veggies. 

Even though the food was bad you would hope for good service to at least off-set the disappointment. Unfortunately the servers here very bad as well, it's so hard to flag any of the two servers in this very tiny restaurant.  When I was dining there, coincidentally friends of the servers were dining there as well. They neglected all the other patrons except their friends especially the guy in the red shirt. He was constantly checking up on his friends to see if they liked the food.  One more thing to mention about him is that he was constantly touching and scratching his pimply face then serving your food......................
author: Lucy C.

description:
A-ok, solid 3. It wasn't disastrous but not something you'd want to eat if you want AMAZING Burmese food. Here's what we ordered for delivery:

Coconut rice- better than bland tasting rice, but didn't have that creamy texture and coconut flavor. And don't be fooled by the small box, they fit in a lot of rice in those things. So, if you're only 2 people, it'll be too much.

Samosas- my favorite of the dishes. Nice and crispy with a potato filling. The sauce that came with it wasn't too spicy either, just enough to get a kick.

Coconut chicken soup- too thick and also lacked the chicken and coconut.

Lemongrass beef- really hard to cut, but had good flavor and the lemongrass was evident.

Garlic noodles- very garlicy, and the noodles lasted well despite not being eaten for a day.  The second star of the meal

Pumpkin prawns- the least favorite. Hardly any shrimp, and not a rich flavor you'd expect. 

So, definitely not comparable to Burma Superstar, but it'll do if you are home and crave some decent Burmese food.
author: Bahar A.

description: The food was decent and the service was hit or miss. We did find a pretty long hair in the signature salad, which we were then comp'd. I think if you are feening for Burmese food, call ahead before the rush of ppl around 7/8pm. Average wait time was about 30/40 minutes.
author: Steve N.

description: High quality meats. They taste great. The sauces taste delicious too. Vegetables are good too. Oily but that's what make food taste good.
author: Robert S.

description:
Love the Burmese food here!  My mom cooks Burmese food and the dishes here rank up there with her cooking.  I usually get Spicy Garlic Fish or Shrimp.  The Tamarind Fish is also very delicious.  The sauces are very flavorful.  

Their Tea Leaf Salad is also a must have.  Every time I come here I am greeted like family.  Friendly wait staff.  Burmese Kitchen is a must try when I'm in the area!
author: Hosick F.

description:
This space is a bit bittersweet to me since my favorite Korean place, To Hyang, used to occupy this space. Although I'm sad that they're no longer here, I am happy to see that another family run establishment has taken it's place. That aside, on to the review!

I really like this place even though I didn't get to try out as many dishes as I wanted. There were only two of us and so we could only order so much. We had the following:

- tea leaf salad
- roasted ginger chicken
- basa fish fillet in tamarind sauce

Overall, both the service and meal were quite good, especially the tea leaf salad. I kept seeing people around me getting the noodle dishes, so I'll definitely have to try that out next time. 

Lastly, given the proximity to B Star and Burma Superstar, for quality, authenticity, and price, I'd definitely recommend this place over the former. So do yourself a favor, give them a shot! :D
author: Ty L.

description: Bermese kitchen had an excellent Tea leaf salad, enough to share for two people. I ordered the Chicken Masala noodles which were delicious with tons of flavor but not an overpowering amount. The home Thai hot tea was a great choice to cleanse the pallet after each bite.
author: Melissa R.

description: Don't call it a comeback and move over Burma Super Star, there is a new king in town. This place rocks so damn hard it's not even funny! I was blown away by how good their food is. Also they don't skimp you on any portions and everything is affordable. The coconuts are fresh and the food is ready faster than you can order it. The staff is friendly, funny and work they ass of making everyone happy. Go there you won't regret it. It will become one of your favorite restaurants.
author: Sr. Misha T.

description:
Disclaimer: My husband's relatives own this restaurant, but my review is as unbiased as can be!

I usually am wary about going to a newly opened restaurant because they still have some kinks to work out, but this was different.  Yes, they were a fully functioning and awesome restaurant before their move, but OMG has it gotten so much better!  Everything tastes fresher.

Roti & potato curry - I LOVE THIS DISH.  My only wish is that they serve it with more roti, but that can be easily solved by ordering 2! :)

Tea leaf salad - When we've ordered this at the old location, it was good.  But when we ordered it this time, the flavors seemed to be brighter, fresher, fuller.  Normally when we would take friends to their previous location, we'd get this just because it is a Burmese staple, but now, I can confidently say that this is THE BEST tea leaf salad I've ever had in the bay area!

Mohinga - fish chowder - A very hearty soup dish that can be eaten as a main dish or shared between 3-4 people.

Dan Pauk - biryani chicken - My hubby's favorite and this was no exception.  The rice is cooked to perfection and the chicken  wonderfully seasoned with curry and other spices.

Spicy fish - The fish is lightly fried and served with a chili/garlic sauce. If you can't handle the heat though, maybe skip this or be sure the rest of your group can.  Hehe.

Chicken curry - can't go wrong with chicken curry!

Coconut rice - This pairs so well with the chicken curry. If you like coconut milk, this is a must try! Don't be afraid, it's not too sweet.  It's a light flavor of coconut milk that's slightly toasted/nutty.

Service is great.  Attentive staff without being overbearing.  Parking is a bit tough, but honestly, this restaurant is well worth the walk and wait.  However, I think the neighborhood is a step up from their last location.  Give Burmese Kitchen a chance!  You won't be disappointed!
author: Roxanne K.

description:
If you enjoy Burmese food, you will like it here.. 
Recommendations:

Tea Leaf Salad
Mohinga which is considered the National Dish of Burma!! 

I've been enjoying this stuff since I was a little kid.. 

This is great and it is delicious!! 

The other Burmese places may be flashier but this place has great food!! Let the food be the decider..
author: Kiel V.

description:
I love this place's aura.  simple, burmese and clean.  we ordered fish chowder and then garlic noodles.  both very good.    the good thing about it is that it is not salty at all. tastes very healthy.

I also tried their Burmese milk tea, which used evaporated milk and has an interesting and good dry flavor.
author: Shuting Z.

description:
We tried burmese food for the first time and it was great. We had the sesame tofu, okra and egg curry and mix vegetable curry along with basmati rice. The sesame tofu was amazing. As vegetarians we usually get the same kind of curry tofu in sauces in most places but this was really different and tasty.

Great choice for vegetarians!
author: Priya G.

description: We regularly frequent Mandalay, Pagan and Burma superstar.  I decided to give this place a chance since it's the only Burmese restaurant that delivers.  Huge disappointment! Everything was soggy from the rainbow salad to the tofu salad.  The eggplant and green beans were inedible, it tasted like it had been sitting under a heat lamp for hours.  Even the coconut rice was terrible.  Sorry Burmese Kitchen! I don't like to write negative reviews but you've got a long way to go considering the neighboring competition.
author: Sara K.

description:
My current favorites: 
Tofu Thok (Golden Tofu Salad) 
Moh Hinga Fish Chowder
Pork with Pickled Mango
Kyat Tha Dan Pauk (Chicken Biryani)
Burmese Milk Tea
Tapioca Dessert

Trust me, this place is legit. My parents were both born and raised in Burma, and we've been twice this week. And they are well aware that Burma Superstar, Mandalay and Pagan are close by. We'll definitely be back soon to try more items.

Also, the owners are splendid - hella nice people. They make every visit a joy.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Wonderful food and great hosts!  So glad to see them finally reopen after their move!
Old lunch favorites are still on the menu, but went for dinner so kept the carbs down, with: BK Tea Leaf Salad (better than ever!), Shrimp with Sour Leaf (most unusual flavor!), and a few bites of Burmese Fried Rice (most interesting variations).  A couple of Samosas for an appetizer (very fat and savory).  As usual, the owners circulate among the guests, both regaling guests with stories of the restaurant business and Burmese cuisine and music and soliciting feedback on how they are doing.  Still tinkering with decor and acoustics, but on their way!  Great night out on Geary!   The new locations is so much better than their old neighborhood, too!
author: A. M.

description:
We were really excited about this Burmese place as their competitors always have a line out the door. Good to have choices.

What was surprisingly good? The tamarind salad. Since neither of us ever heard of it, we gave it a try. The texture is a bit different for us, but it was pretty tasty. Lots of sesame seeds.

The Samosa was just okay.

The Sautéed Spicy Lady Finger was disappointing. This is stir-fried okra but the okra is soggy unlike the other places where the okra is slightly crunchy. It's also not that tasty and pretty bland dish. While I am really not into salty food, this dish was really lack-luster.

Overall, just ok. We probably won't be back.
author: Missy X.

description: The best Burmese restaurant in town. The tea leaf salad is the best. Fish chowder was delicious, everything was really good. Could not have found a better place in San Francisco.
author: Erik Y.

description: Came with 2 friends and was seated shortly even though there were a lot of people. The tea salad was tasty, lots of nuts and even better than Burma Superstar. Ordered the string beans, which was flavorful. The sweet and sour meat dish was tasty according to my friends.
author: Rosanna T.

description:
Not very impressed by Burmese Kitchen. I feel like each dish was missing something to make it flavorful and enjoyable. The meat cuts for the pork and pumpkin were tough.

It was just a night full of mistakes to try them, never again.
author: A W.

description: Ordered the tea leaf salad. Deliciously authentic. The atmosphere here is also very nice. The owner is very friendly. Definitely supporting this neighborhood gem #supportsmallbusiness
author: Rachelle L.

description: Came here for a friend's birthday dinner around 7pm on a Saturday night. We only had to wait less than 10 mins for a table. They have a sign up sheet with a lot of names already on it, guess we got there at the perfect time. The place was already full. They don't take reservations for less than 6 people. Their prices is cheaper than the other Burmese restaurants I've been too. We ordered the samosas, roti, fish soup, beef masala, and garlic noodles. I thought that everything could be seasoned a bit more. The samosas could use more curry, the beef masala could use more spices, the garlic noodles could use more garlic and the noodles was cooked too long, it was too soft. Overall food was pretty good. Service is a bit slow. We ordered a bottle of wine and it came after 3 dishes of ours had already came out.
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description: The absolutely most authentic Burmese food I have found in SF.  The Roti and Potato curry is great as is the tea leaf salad and the curry coconut chicken.   The staff is very kind and friendly and I have enjoyed their food for years.   Started dining with them at their old location and this one is much nicer...
author: Will M.

description:
I really enjoyed the food and service here. I've never been to Burma, but this is what I expect authentic Burmese food to taste like. 

We started off with the tea leaf salad. Not too sure what people are talking about, but the portion and ratio of tea leaves to the other ingredients gave the salad a great fresh flavor. 

After indulging on the salad, we got the chicken curry with some coconut rice. I personally love all things coconut and rice is no exception. The rice had just the right amount of stickiness and coconut flavor. The spices in the curry was also good. I loved it since it was the right amount of spice for my palate. 

The service was very attentive and I enjoyed the staff. 

Overall, great value especially for the quality and flavor. I definitely will be back.
author: Nate C.

description:
Meh. Neither my friend nor I were impressed by our meals. I tried to order two dishes that they were out of, so I ended up getting the garlic eggplant. It lacked flavor and some of the pieces of eggplant did not seem fully cooked. We also got a ginger salad, which started off tasty but it was overdressed and after a few bites it was hard to continue eating it. The rice was overcooked and there was something "off" about it. Lastly we had garlic noodles. Those were the best because the veggies were steamed, so the dish was healthy, which I appreciate. Just don't expect sauce or much flavor other than crunchy garlic on top. 

Overall I was excited to have another Burmese spot but unfortunately this place did not live up to SF standards.
author: S Z.

description: I'm so glad I followed Burmese Kitchen to their new location. Despite the handful of Burmese restaurants in the area, none rival their exquisite flavor, and level of attentiveness and friendliness. In my personal opinion, they have the best tea leaf salad around. I also love the yellow pea dish and biryani rice with saffron. A wonderful option for vegans! This place is a gem!
author: A S.

description: The food was SO DELICIOUS! Some of the best meat I've ever had. Their pork curry is to die for. Excellent service; cosy atmosphere. The restaurant owners/cooks really care about the food they're serving and it really shows. I will most definitely be back! My new local favorite.
author: Teresa L.

description: The flavors and textures are amazing. No need to wait around the corner at Burma Superstar, this spot checks all the boxes.
author: Debra K.

description:
Great Burmese food. We like the Mohinga, tea salad, and garlic noodles!

It's usually less crowded than Burma Superstar and quite good.  Parking is a little easier toio
author: Jonathan J.

description: This place has a very warm and family-friendly feel to it. I am Burmese myself and I can say that the food has an authenticity to it and tastes great too. The owner is extremely friendly and the service is tip top. Definitely would recommend to anyone who is looking for some delicious and authentic Burmese food.
author: Stanley K.

description:
Had a very good lunch. Staff was attentive and friendly, the food was remarkable, relative and healthy. 

Highly recommended. Lunch specials nice full meal for under $10.

The desserts are just as amazing
author: T M.

description: I absolutely love Burmese tea leaf salads, so it was a must-order dish for me. They have 2 different types of tea leaf salad, a regular tea leaf salad and the signature tea leaf salad that comes with more fermented tea leaves. I recommend ordering the signature tea leaf salad. It was definitely delicious, but the only thing was that it was a small portion. We ended up having to order 2 of them to have enough for 3 people. The fish chowder was delicious, was spicier than I had anticipated it would be, but was still manageable. We also ordered the lady fingers (okra), which was a nice veggie dish. Overall, this place was a pretty good Burmese restaurant - definitely a place to try if you'd like to try Burmese food and avoid the long line at Burma Superstar.
author: Kyle S.

description: We ordered Burmese Kitchen for delivery. The food was delicious. However, there were some disappointments and I won't be ordering from them again. First, they forgot one of our dishes despite us being charged for it. We had to call them and ask about it. We ended up getting a refund for that dish but it was kind of a hassle and we were looking forward to that entree :( The second disappointment, which to me is the main dealbreaker, is the portion sizes. I thought the prices were so reasonable until we saw the amount of food. Let's just say we spent $65 before tax/tip/delivery fee, and we had zero leftovers after the 2 of us had dinner. I was really surprised at the small quantities, and won't repeat business based on that.
author: Anna J.

description: Burmese Kitchen is just the best. It's delicious and has a low-key family vibe. Every dish is perfectly executed, fresh and flavorful. They also have a lot of healthy options, like tea leaf salad and light but rich okra. I'd eat here over Burma Superstar any day.
author: George W.

description: This place is amazing. Their fermented green tea salad tops all of the other nearby Burmese places! GO!
author: Majd M.

description: Been to all the other Burmese restaurants in this city, but Burmese kitchen continues to be my favorite. Their old location was where I was introduced to them, but their new location is closer to home, so I'm pleased!
author: Laura H.

description:
Thank you Burmese Kitchen for hosting AAWAA's Eating for Artists event. 
We had a great time. The food was delish, the staff friendly, and the owners is super nice and helpful. We had a pretty big crowd and they handled it professionally and seated folks quickly.
Many of our guests had never been there before and said that they would definitely be back. 
I had the Lamb with Pickled Mango with coconut rice DELISH.  
We will be back.
author: Sig A.

description:
What a find! Came here to try it after hearing it reopened--and it was such a good decision! The restaurant itself is intimate, a great spot for a date night. The orange wall and clean wooden tables give it a nice modern look while still remaining comfy and welcoming.

We had: 

Tea Leaf Salad--Best one in the city, and we've tried them all. It isn't too spicy, is a great portion, and very flavorful.

Samosas--So good! Not greasy at all, and stuffed with deliciously seasoned potatoes and peas...

Roti--Thousand layer bread, so delicate and flaky. mmm

Beef & Potato Curry--The beef was so tender and juicy--it melted in your mouth. The potatoes were hot and perfectly cooked, and the curry spices were just right. Exactly what we were looking for on a cold, rainy SF night. 

Tapioca Pudding--brought my fiancee back to her childhood. It was prepared just like her grandma used to make, warm with a bit of coconut/condensed milk. She was in heaven.

And our server--Lee was very sweet to take a few minutes to chat with us about the old location and the new one. She was quick and very busy with many full tables!

Overall--they prices were fair for the right amount of food, and you can taste the love and family recipes. So satisfying, and might be habit forming. 

We will definitely be back!
author: Mariko S.

description: Most people will never get the chance to travel to Burma but a trip (preferably many) to the Burmese Kitchen will bring you to the Far East through each of its authentic plates. Each bite and sip of tea at BK brings me back to my days living in Burma--the owners offer a unique experience by welcoming all guests to taste the best of Burma's culture, such as Mohinga and lahpet thoke (tea leaf salad) which the owner personally travels to Burma to bring back the tea leaves. Best of SF!
author: Carolyn W.

description: One of our best meals as long as we can remember!  Everything was tasty and delicious.  Nice atmosphere and cordial service!  We loved the tea salad, chicken coconut curry, basil fish, stir-fried okra, with coconut rice and biryani... Topped with tapioca with coconut milk for dessert. Perfect in every way!
author: thu b.

description: I tried this place out and ordered the basics.  I have to say that I was quite disappointed.  The flavor that I have come to expect from Burmese food was not there in the dishes that I tried.  I do not intend to return.
author: Gwynessa B.

description: Best Burmese food in San Francisco. Hands down! Authentic and the price is reasonable. I've been a frequent guest at the old location, and now it is further from where I reside. I still would head to the new location! Love this place!!
author: Lily Ann L.

description: Pretty great place, it's usually really hard to get a table and always A line outside. If you're into Burmese food, this place will not disappoint. Best Burmese in town!
author: Esther F.

description: This place is the bomb! I eat the lunch special 3 times a week. Small tea leaf salad to start, then tamarind fish and yellow peas. I like that it's not super crowded all the time like Burma Superstar. You walk in and immediately order, and the food is pretty quick.
author: Josh J.

description: I typically love Burmese food, but I wasn't a fan of the food I ordered here. Tried the tea leaf salad (didn't taste very fresh), garlic noodles (quite flavorless & noodles were partially hard/overcooked), samolina cake (just okay) -- the only dish I enjoyed was the chicken coconut curry. However, it probably wasn't enough to make me come back. I hate to encourage the "mainstream" choice, but in this case, Burma Superstar really stands out as the superior option for Burmese food in the area.
author: Kristina W.

description: I didn't think I would encounter another restaurant that could give Burma Superstar a run for its money but Burmese Kitchen is absolutely delicious.  I loved their tea leaf salad, roti, chicken curry and biryani rice. I also couldn't stop oogling at the food at other tables so I can't wait to go back with the hubby and try something new.
author: C L.

description:
LOVE this restaurant! Atmosphere and service are great and the food, most importantly, is amazing. I've eaten here twice so far and both times have been equally satisfying. This place beats Burma Superstar without a doubt; it's way more authentic and food tastes fresher. Although it's busy, it's still fairly new so not too many people know about it (which is great because I frankly hate waiting in lines!). Coming back here next week for round three! See below for recommended orders.

What we loved:
Tea Leaf Salad. This is light yet hardy, fresh and delicious. 
Roti & Potato Curry: this was a wild card for us but turned out to be excellent! Very filling and flavorful.
Chin Baung Hin Yay Fish & Sour Leaf: This is SPICY and so delicious. I'm not a fan of fish soups but this was seriously so good! Incredibly flavorful, not overpowering, spicy - but just the right amount, and hardy! 
Garlic Chicken: three other tables ordered the same thing and each of us were in awe at how perfectly tender and delicious this dish was. We even eyed each other in affirmation of heavenly cooked the meat was -- so juicy!
author: June L.

description:
We went for lunch. Reasonably priced. Good portions. My husband ordered the "Meatlover" lunch plate: a choice of 1 meat dish, and 1 vegetable dish for $11 including steamed rice. Add $1 for coconut rice, brown rice, fried rice or biryani rice.  He chose the pork with pickled mango, pumpkin stew, and biryani rice - all for $12. (Their lunch menu is posted online).

I ordered the Soup and Salad for $12. Choice of soup: fish chowder, samosa soup, or chicken coconut noodle soup. Choice of salad: tea leaf or ginger salad. The salad was small but sufficient. The chicken coconut noodle soup was good and filled me, and I left satisfied.

The owner was very friendly. He said he was testing out the lunch hours. So far it has been slow at lunch, but busy at dinnertime. If lunch remains slow, he may close for lunch and offer only dinner hours.  So folks, come on down.  Keep this place open at lunchtime, please!
author: Kaykay K.

description:
We have been going to Burmese Kitchen since it opened at its previous location on Larkin Street and have come to prefer it to some of the other popular Burmese restaurants in San Francisco because we find the food to be really exceptional and unique. It's also great that you don't have to wait in line for an hour! If you're a vegetarian you will be very satisfied by the options at Burmese Kitchen: Vegetarian food doesn't get more delicious and nutritious than this! We especially love the Golden Tofu Salad, which is unlike anything we'd ever tried before. Not to be confused with standard tofu made from soybeans, this tofu is made in house from yellow beans. I'm not sure what goes into the salad (fried onions, definitely) but it is so rich and tasty I could easily eat it every day. The tea leaf salad is amazing too (order the signature one for an extra generous helping of tea leaves), as is the tamarind salad, the samusas and the roti. If you eat seafood and enjoy spice you may like the spicy fish, fish soup with sour vegetables, or fish chowder (more mild). The pumpkin prawns are good too. Because my husband doesn't eat meat other than seafood, we haven't really tried many of the meat options, though some friends did order a chicken stew of some kind that they seemed to really enjoy. 
As a final note, we love the management here! They're always really kind and genuine and have been so friendly towards our young son, who is fast becoming a fan of Burmese cuisine. All in all, one of our very favorite restaurants in town!
author: E. K.

description: Love the food and love the service! We can never understand why people wait in line for Burma star when this establishment is just as good if not better. The prices are reasonable as well which is a plus! We have eaten here three times and not once have we ever been disappointed in any aspect of our dining experience.
author: Lauraine E.

description: Honey and I came here for dinner to try her favorite cuisine, Burmese. The place is family-like and small, also looks like a hole in the wall, which is fine. We ordered the tea leaf salad and a few other dishes. The tea leaf salad did stand out and was tasty. Price was affordable and reasonable. We would come back here again.
author: Allan W.

description: Superb Food. Great tea leaf salad, and delicious coconut chicken. Coconut rice is a really nice addition.
author: Uddhav A.

description: I ordered the garlic chicken from Uber eats and was so dissapointed by the quality of the meal. The meat was inedible and sauce pure water.
author: Tina C.

description: The Tea Leaf Salad it amazing. It was light, yummy and had an amazing aroma. The food is reasonably priced, but a little on the expensive side for the curries in my opinion.
author: Toni A.

description:
Not impressive by any means 

Had a dish of mango salad as I wanted to taste something other than tea leaf salad .. It was ok with quite less quantity for 10$ and then had garlic noodles which was quite not sauted as well. There was no taste as such and was really bland. When this was mentioned to server his only response was to get some soy sauce.

The ambience of this place is not so nice. Regular table chairs with minimum deco
author: Y U.

description:
We had garlic noodles, golden tofu, and the fish chowder, and they were mostly bland.  We ate only a little of the tofu and didn't even bother taking the rest home.

Came in at lunch time, only 1 other table was occupied, and the another person waiting for take out.  Still the service was slow.  We sat for 5 minutes and had to ask for glasses of water.

A bit of disappointment, but luckily there's still Mandalay and Burma Superstar in the 'hood.
author: daphne w.

description: There's a lot to love about this place. The tea leaf salad (get the extra fermented one) is delicious in flavor and texture, and as much as I love Burma Superstar I think this one is my favorite. Lots of awesome fish and veggie options and super friendly staff. I make it a point to visit here every time I'm in SF.
author: Andy H.

description:
We usually go to Volcano Curry when we're in this neighborhood, but we decided to try this place because we haven't had Burmese in a while. We started with the tea leaf salad, which was very tasty.  You could really taste the fermented tea leaves and that contrasted really well with the crispy peas, peanuts, cabbage, & garlic chips. Next we had the roti with the yellow potato curry.  We both commented that it was excellent comfort food. The bread was nice and hot, and there were big chunks of potato in the curry. The roti was pretty small, so we had to eat some curry without bread, but it was still excellent. Next came the garlic egg noodles. They weren't very special - definitely the least inspired dish, but I did like the crispy garlic in it.  Finally we had the lemongrass beef. I don't think I've ever had this dish before, so the closest comparison I can come up with is mas-su-man beef.  It was the same style of stewed beef, with a similar type of gravy on it, but with a milder flavor. 
It's a cute little restaurant and the service was quick and friendly. We'll definitely be back and this time order two of the tea salads and two of the roti with the yellow potato curry.
author: Quentin J.

description: The tea leaf salad was good. I was not excited about my entrees though. Maybe I just ordered the wrong thing.
author: Bill O.

description: Burmese kitchen has some really great burmese food. We ordered the yellow curry, fried rice, tea leaf salad, and something else. Everything was so delicious. I would say that if you want to avoid the crowd over other burmese restaurants, this would be a great place to go. The ambience is so welcoming and homey. The service was also great. Loved it!
author: Justina L.

description:
Hmm... where do I begin...

We were across the street, in the process of buying a car at the Toyota Scion. 
While waiting for all the paperwork to process, I asked our salesman about the place. 
He actually recommended B-star. But the walk was too far. We decided instead to just walk across the street to the "grand opening" of Burmese Kitchen. Big mistake. 

I didn't care for the dingy bathroom, which I had to use before lunch. But whatever...
When the roti and curry arrived, I was like, 'where is the rest of the roti?'. I've NEVER been served ONE roti bread at a time. Must be a Burmese thing. Oh well... the roti and sauce was good though. 

I ordered the tamarind fish soup which was absolutely AWFUL. The spices didn't blend well together. I couldn't make out what was what, just a bunch of seasonings which still failed to make the dish savory. 

My husband ordered the ginger chicken with fried rice. The chicken was rubbery and dry,  smothered in a dark reddish-brown ginger-ish sauce. Again, strange seasoning marinated in stale meat, equals BAD combination. Not impressed. 

Hubby also ordered fried rice. Not impressed either. The serving was small and barely covered the plate. I guess that was a good thing, as it didn't taste all that good either. Its not your standard fried rice, it was a brownish looking rice with a few beans in it. That's it. It would help if the servers would explain what their 'fried rice' is before one orders. 

We ordered a plate of coconut rice. THat was the best dish, after the roti and curry appetizer. Nothing crazy good about it, it just wasn't BAD like all the other fails. The only complaint was the scanty serving though.

I didn't even go into the ditzy waitress we had. She literally STOOD over us the whole time, as we were seated right next to the 'phone' desk. Those who have been here know where I'm talking about. I will NEVER COME BACK.
author: Providence D.

description: Just ok. We ordered delivery tonight. Samosas were incredible. Tea leaf salad was also quite good (not like Burma or Mandalay though). We were quite disappointed with our entrees: coconut chicken curry and vegetable curry. Both were clumpy and bland. Adding rooster sauce didn't even help. Coconut rice was excellent! For $50, not worth our money.
author: Ms. B.

description: Burmese Kitchen is hands down a must-eat restaurant with great, authentic food and a friendly atmosphere. The food's high quality and affordability make this restaurant far superior to the bland, culture-less, so-called "Asian" restaurants in other popular (US) cities. The Tea Leaf Salad, Fried Samosas, Beef Biryani, and Fish with Tamarind Sauce were particularly splendid.
author: Abbas A.

description:
Best Burmese food I've had (beside Mom's) at very reasonable prices!

Two tea leaf salad--definitely order the house special tea leaf salad!
Plump, spicy (and not greasy!) samosas
Sour leaf vegetable with shrimp (finally found a place that has my fave after all these years!)
Two biryanis (chicken and beef)

There are lots more, but these are the only ones that I can remember!  Most of the items hover around $10-$12/dish so it's about $ to $$.

Definitely go try it out, if you haven't tried it yet!
author: Aggie A.

description:
I was a regular at their old location in the Tenderloin. This new venue is bright, clean, and spacious. It is a huge improvement. 

The food is every bit as good: the tea leaf salad is a must-have; the spicy fish is as described and very garlicky as well. The service is friendly and easygoing. 

It's what makes the city great. Casual, cheap, and high quality. 

The owner told me lunch business is light but dinner is much more popular, compared to downtown. For a neighborhood place, this is fantastic. I had been wanting to get there to check it out. I would recommend it even if you have to drive: it is excellent.
author: Frank W.

description: Great food whether youre familiar with Burmese or not. First time at their new location and even though a bit further to go, well worth the trip. Love the Ohn-No Khao Swè. Be worth 6 stars when they get the liquor license.
author: vambo r.

description: Really really good.  Truly interesting and creative food.
author: Trecker J.

description: The tea leaf salad was wonderful. So was the tamarind fish -- service was very friendly. Although the place was small, they accommodated a group of 6 well. Prices great!!!!
author: RD S.

description: found this place through UberEats.   Ordered the Spice Beef Jerky (good), Garlic Chicken (good and with lots of garlic), Tea Leaf Salad (excellent) and Garlic Egg Noodle (ok - not sure what the hype on this dish was all about.  Will definitely try other dishes from the restaurant.
author: Hoa T.

description: Tea Leaf Salad is fantastic. Also my first time sitting at a community table, which allows you to get seated much faster with another party. Don't worry though, they won't bug you!
author: Chris O.

description: Great food! Coconut chicken soup, tea leaf salad of course and lemongrass beef. Burmese iced coffee is more on the light watery side compared to a thai or Vietnamese iced coffee. Really friendly service. To prevent wait time makes reservation
author: Juliana L.

description: What a surprising treat!!! Haven't had biryani this good since being in India. I've only tried once and look forward to seeing if they can keep up their consistency with the quality of food.
author: Rahman P.

description:
3.5 stars

Had the roti with potato curry, moh hinga, special tea leaf salad, chicken curry, pork & pumpkin, mixed vegetable curry and coconut rice. The dishes had flavor but didn't have something distinctive to make them stand out. While the moh hinga was tasty, the chicken in the chicken curry was not fresh. Both Burma Superstar and Mandalay do a slightly better job. Service was attentive and it was easy to get in which is a strong positive for Burmese Kitchen.
author: Chew B.

description: Would go back for the salad and simosas, the coconut curry chicken was good. Excellent service, very nice and attentive, the owner was there talking to some other people which gave it a nice homey feel. It was almost empty, but it was also after 9 at the beginning of summer. Prices were pretty reasonable.
author: Nobumi S.

description: This is the best Burmese food I have had since I went to Myanmar last year. The tea leaf salad is authentic, the mohinga soup is delicious, and the mixed vegetable curry was tasty. I enjoyed a cup of burmese milk tea while I waited for the food, this was also quite authentic. You must try this restaurant!
author: Katelyn S.

description: Go! I was bummed when I found out this restaurant closed their Civic Center location down in the Ls, and delighted to find out it's been reincarnated in the Richmond. Tasty & Authentic!
author: Karen C.

description: Very meh. With so many excellent Burmese options in the area I wouldn't really go back unless they improved
author: A S.

description: There are not many great Burmese restaurant in SF and when I stumble upon Burmese Kitchen I was super excited. I came here first time and disappointed that food was mediocre and waiter was spacey and numb. Sooo disappointed because I really really want to like this place. I was hoping this can be the place to host family and friends dinner but all that ended when the food arrived. So sad.....
author: Ellen T.

description: The food wasn't at the level of Burma Superstar or Mandalay, but it was cheaper and there was no wait. They were out of all the desserts except for the samolina cake, which I wouldn't recommend.
author: Brian M.

description: The prawn and pumpkin was not fresh and salty. The string bean dish was ok. The vegetarian curry has a few pcs of main vegetables except for broccoli. Nothing special. The tea leaf salad is not too bad. Sorry, I will not recommend this restaurant.
author: Melvon M.

description: Very small but nice restaurant. Portion is very little. The food is okay. Staff are very attentive. We like the garlic noodles and Roti.
author: Michelle L.

description: V good. V authentic. V quick service. V polite. V helpful. V good suggestions. Had the pork w pickled mango, coconut rice, roti, signature tea leaf salad, Spicy lotus, hot milk tea....all v good. V recommend everything.
author: Juan T.

description: Came in here on a Friday night for dinner. The decor is nice and the vibe is cozy. Their menu has so many items to offer so we asked for some recommendations. We started off with a Tamarind salad. The taste is hard to describe but it's insanely good. Then we had a fish & sour leaf soup which was a bit spicy and well-balanced. For our main courses, we had a chicken coconut curry which was tasty and creamy, and a beef masala. They were delishhhhh! Oh, and  a tip for drinks: they have Burmese beer! Overall, it was a great experience. We will definitely be back and try more of the dishes! :D
author: Emily J.

description:
This was my first time at the new location and the place is clean and nicely decorated.  The staff is friendly and attentive.  I went on a  Friday evening and they were packed!  I usually don't go to Burmese restaurants because my folks make it at home and that's pretty much what I eat almost everyday.  However, Burmese Kitchen is a great place to take your friends out and try different things on the menu because hey, Burmese restaurants are pretty rare.  This place has legit Burmese food and reminds me of everything I love about Burmese cuisines.

Roti and Curry - Delicious!  The roti is a thicker kind and it's delicious with almost anything, in this case, potato curry!  Vegetarian option.

Mohinga - international dish of Burma.  I tried this dish in other Burmese restaurants, but this one hits home.  It's burmese catfish soup with noodle and fried yellow pea.  This dish is eaten as breakfast, lunch, and/or dinner in Burma.  

Coconut chicken curry (Oh nok kaw swe) - I personally prefer this over mohinga.  Both are very delicious.

Tea leaf salad - this dish is hyped here more than in Burma.  It's a mix of tea leaf, nuts, sesame, some veggies, and tomato.  It's fresh and uniquely Burmese.

Fish with Tamarine Sauce - this was my favorite dish.  The fish was tender and had the perfect flavor with rice.  Highly recommended!

Other dishes to consider:
- Pork with Pickled Mango
- Spicy shrimp
- Nan Ji Thok - rice noodle mixed with veggies and chicken.  This doesn't come in soup, but is still tasty!
- Burmese tea - Burmese tea houses are big in Burma (similar to tea houses in China).   You gotta try the tea for the full Burmese experience.

Overall, my experience at Burmese Kitchen was positive.  Friendly staff and great food!
author: Sammantha T.

description: A hidden gem, given that most people go to Burma Superstar and Mandalay nearby. Their tea leaf salad, eggplant with garlic sauce, chicken masala and the garlic noodles are our favorite dishes.  Definitely skip the lines elsewhere and try Burmese Kitchen.
author: Liz O.

description: Been there yesterday night with friends. We gave it a shot knowing that Burma Superstar had closed. And we were not disappointed..!! The chicken curry was superb to say the least. Their ambiance was pretty inviting and the price was less than 10 bucks for a person..!! If you want to try a new Burmese cuisine that is authentic, this is the place for you..!! (I do hope it gets a lot of reviews here on)
author: Ram R.

description: We dined at the Kitchen last night and quite frankly, were underwhelmed. The food was Burmese allright but did not measure up to The BStar or Mingalaba. Spices were too mild. To make the experience further uncomfortable, there were too many fruit flies in our face all night..This may be a good place for take out if you like certain items on the menu but we did not enjoy sitting and dining there.
author: Ravi S.

description: Excellent, authentic, 'home cooked' Burmese food backed by friendly service.  It doesn't get much better.
author: critic c.

description: Great burmese falafel and veggie curry! Burmese Kitchen is a much quicker and affordable alternative to Burma Superstar or B Star, earning it 5 stars
author: Troy D.

description: The mango salad was slightly salty, and the pork with mango pickle was an delightful surprise. Next time will have to try the fried oakra.
author: Vikas M.

description: Delicious, delicately flavored food; best I've had in a long time. Very reasonably priced. Nice service. I'd definately go again.
author: Braden W.

description:
I discovered Burma Kitchen in their old location on Larkin St. I had many delicious lunches there & was bummed when they closed. Imagine my delight when they re-opened in my neighborhood! Yay!

The food is fabulous and the prices are reasonable, this place is so much better than Superstar or Mandalay. I've been working my way through the menu (except for pork & beef) and haven't had a bad thing yet, although I don't recommend getting samosas for takeout because they get soggy when they get cold. Most things have been good, some even spectacular. I wasn't terribly impressed with the pumpkin stew but it was my personal taste, not anything they did wrong. Favorites are the tea leaf salad (always fresh & with plenty of tea leaves) and garlic noodles and potato curry and the fried combo starter. Yum.
author: Stacey H.

description: Not good. Tea leaf salad was all peanuts. Tea leaves flavorless. Samosas were filled with unspiced mashed potatoes. Bad food presentation. Go to Mandalay, B-Star or Burma Superstar.
author: Hilary K.

description: My wife and I came in here on a lark. A few years ago we traveled through myanmar together and at that moment we were craving some burmese food :) We ordered the tamarind fish, ohn noh khao swhe (spelling check) and a bowl of mohinga. Everything was fantastic! The fish was so good we ordered a second plate!
author: Anthony R.

description:
I've always wanted to try this restaurant but never made it to the Larkin location, so I was thrilled to see it open in my neighborhood. 
My family's from Burma so I had to order the more traditional dishes like Mo Hing Nga (fish chowder noodle soup), Ching Maw Jaw (shrimp and sour leaves), curry chicken, kow soy dok (noodle dish)... We were impressed, especially with the fish chowder noodle soup and flavorful curry chicken! We'll be going back to try other dishes. We ordered the Balachan/Malachan to go. This tastes so good just over plain rice! 
There were eight of us. The service was friendly and efficient. Go check it out!
author: A L.

description: It was my second time here and I enjoyed the food. I had the garlic chicken and the garlic noodles with chicken. I loved the garlic chicken with large pieces of chicken and garlic, and vegetables with rice that was soft and moist, and the noodles were good yet I thought that they could have some additional spice and flavor. Leigh, the owner, was friendly and helpful. My friend ordered a Tamarind salad and said she could not find this salad at other Burmese places (not sure how many she checked). The homemade iced tea was delicious. The place is casual. They moved from the downtown area and I like it better in the Richmond area. A family style place.
author: Donna C.

description: I love Burmese food! Went here for lunch, no wait and easy metered parking, delicious food though small portions of tea leaf salad for lunch special. Very nice people, think the owner was working there. I'll definitely be returning for dinner some time.
author: L J.

description: This place makes me happy; the recipes are tasty and the atmosphere is lovely.  This is a family ran business.  They make you feel welcome each time you return.
author: C B.

description: Food was delicious!  The ginger chicken was so incredibly tender with tasty basmati rice.  There was a little bit of a wait for the food which meant they actually cooked the food and not just heated in microwave.
author: W.L. H.

description: Great food!  Bustling little pop up with spotty service but forgivable because of it's mom and pop feeling. This was the first Burmese food I've had that actually reminded me of the food I had in Myanmar. The salads are not as pretty as Burma Superstar but taste more authentic. We had the Roti, Tamarind leaf salad, tamarind fish and coconut chicken noodle soup. All delicious. The table next to us had a huge plate of biriani that looked really tasty. I need to come back!  Prices are very reasonable and beers are $3.50. There's wine by the glass for $6 but it isn't very good.  The service is well intentioned but forgetful. We had to remind them about what we ordered and they forgot a few things. But it was a busy Friday night and there was a big table of 8 having a birthday.
author: Priscilla C.

description: Excellent food but the portions for take out were very small. Excellent website for ease of ordering.
author: Margot K.

description: So good. Love their tea leaf/ginger salads, the coconut rice, and tofu salad and pumpkin curry. Their new location is nicer/fancier inside that their old place.
author: glass e.

description: I dream about Burmese Kitchen's tea leaf salad, ginger salad, spicy sliced bamboo and falafel soup. These dishes are authentic, flavorful, fresh and wonderful. We're vegetarian and love the variety of veggie dishes that aren't simply a meat dish made with tofu. The decor is simple and clean. The staff is friendly and helpful. We miss lunch at the Tenderloin location but love getting dinner at the new location -- easy parking and hardly any wait. A real winner.
author: Wendy T.

description: We had a generally ok experience there, but I wouldn't go back. There are 3 other, better (for the same price) Burmese restaurants within a 2-3 minute walk. Since they're a "pop-up", the place has a temporary feel and looked dark and somewhat dingy (front window was filthy). Service was mediocre. Food was ok, nothing special for Burmese. I was happy to at least see that they had some wine selection.
author: Melissa M.

description: Excellent home cooked food.  Ordered the tea leaf salad, ginger chicken, and garlic chicken, and a lime juice.  Don't except fancy, just good authentic food and you can't beat the price!
author: Sarah A.

description: Back in SF for a visit after moving to NYC a year ago, I've been craving Burmese food and was sad to hear Burmese Kitchen in the Loin had closed. Quick research revealed the new location on Geary, and it did not disappoint! The tea leaf salad was delicious as was the sour leaf fish soup.  I remember meeting the owner years ago when he first opened in the Loin, and I wish him many more happy years of brisk business in the new location.
author: Ms. M N.

description: Came here twice ordered the same but the food consistency is not well maintained.Not much of a spice and taste just okay would prefer to have a delicious tea leaf and mangoe salad somewhere else in the city.Server are not so attentive and they choose only who they want to engage with !Thus this will be my last time.I hope they will improve if I decided to come again.
author: Aries G.

description: I rarely eat out for Burmese food. My parents are from Burma, so I tend to be disappointed with the Burmese restaurants out there. However, I was utterly surprised at how authentic the food is here. My friends enjoy Burmese cuisine, so we decided to come to Burmese Kitchen based off of the reviews. We ordered family style and everyone, including myself, was beyond satisfied with this decision. Like the reviews mention, the tea leaf salad is one of the best that I've had; it's just like the home-made ones. Of all of the dishes, my favorite was the fish noodle soup (mohinga), the biryani rice with chicken, and the shrimp and sour leaf. My friends loved the coconut noodle soup and spicy fish. To be honest, everything that we ate was delicious. They could not stop raving about the food and how it was one of the best they've had in the city. Also, I found out that Burmese Kitchen caters. I would definitely consider ordering some dishes for my next work potluck event. Everyone always asks me to bring home-made Burmese cuisine. I've found a place that I would be happy to vouch for as authentic.
author: Carolyn L.

description: Wow! I'm a big Burmese food fan and I'm so glad I found this place. I went for lunch on a Sunday and had an excellent meal. The service was lovely and food was amazing. We started with the special BK tea leaf salad which is like normal tea leaf salad with extra tea leaves so it has a more intense flavor that I really enjoyed. We also ordered roti with curry, nan gyi thok, coconut rice, okra, and the pickled mango pork. Everything was great but the pork was absolutely delicious- flavorful, tender, and a tiny bit sour. I highly recommend!
author: Natalie G.

description: Not that the neighborhood really needed another Burmese joint, but Im glad these nice folks relocated to my neck of the woods! The food is most excellent and there is no line to get in. I usually go with take out after work so I can't say much of the wait staff except that everyone has been nothing but genuinely nice every time I've been in. The Tea leaf salad is covered in sesame seed goodness, the Garlic Chicken is amazing with the Coconut rice. And my friends that have had other dishes have had nothing but good things to say about them as well. Welcome to the Inner Richmond guys, hope you stick around!!
author: Tom K.

description: This restaurant used to be in the Tenderloin; the Inner Richmond location is new. We were greeted by a very homey atmosphere, with the music turned just a little lower than the volume of conversation, and no greeter/gatekeeper at the door. But the waiter was attentive and seated us right away. The tea was a good temperature, properly steeped, and happened to be imported from Burma. We ordered a tea leaf salad, the samusa soup and the boiled eggs in tamarind sauce. The salad cannot compare to the famed tea lead salad of Burma Superstar lore, but it was reasonably good. The samusa soup was tasty and very healthy. The boiled eggs in tamarind sauce was a new experience, and tasted much like an Indian curry. Very flavorful and highly recommended. The service was very friendly and helpful - even engaging us in conversation long after the other customers had left and never making us feel like it was time to go (despite the fact that we stayed quite late!).
author: Nikhil V.
